questions.question_text: A network engineer must remove a device that has been allowlisted. How should the engineer remove it manually on Cisco ISE?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Endpoint Id Groups is in the Groups subpath
Administration > Identity Management > Groups > Endpoint Identity Groups

Selected Answer: B
Administration > Identity Management > Groups > Endpoint Identity Groups.
There is no Admin > Identity Management > Endpoint Identity Group in the menu (ISE 2.7)

Selected Answer: B
Endpoint Identity Groups is in the Groups subpath

Selected Answer: B
To remove a device that has been allowlisted manually on Cisco ISE, the correct answer is option - Administration > Identity Management > Groups > Endpoint Identity Groups. This option allows you to view and edit the endpoint identity groups that are configured on Cisco ISE, and to delete any device that belongs to a specific group.

choices.C: The command dot1x critical vlan 40 is not configured on the switch ports.
choices.D: The endpoint firewalls are blocking the EAPoL traffic.
choices.B: The switch’s supplicant is unable to establish a connection to Cisco ISE.
choices.A: The command dot1x system-auth-control is not configured on the switch.

questions.question_text: An engineer is adding a new network device to be used with 802.1X authentication. After configuring the device, the engineer notices that no endpoints that connect to the switch are able to authenticate. What is the problem?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Based on the information given in the question, the most likely cause of the authentication failure is option - The command dot1x system-auth-control is not configured on the switch. This command enables 802.1X authentication globally on the switch and is required for the switch to function as an authenticator. Without this command, the switch will not initiate the authentication process with the endpoints.

comments.content: denverfly's response is sound. I know this from experience. Devices will not authenticate through 802.1x without the global command on the switch. The question is asking why end points that connect to the switch are not able to authenticate making option A the only feasible answer.
agree with you I think it is something not related to the configuration because they sayed that the switch is configured, so I have an hesitation between B and D
Your own response proves A isn't the right answer. Re-read the question.

choices.E: access control list to filter the IOS commands

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD

An administrator must provide administrative access to the helpdesk users on production Cisco IOS routers. The solution must meet these requirements:

These configurations have been performed:
• joined Cisco ISE to AD
• retrieved AD groups
• added a router to Cisco ISE
• enabled Device Admin Service in Cisco ISE
• configured an authorization policy
• configured the routers for authentication and authorization

Which two components must be configured? (Choose two.)

B looks like the good answer

questions.question_text: An engineer is starting to implement a wired 802.1X project throughout the campus. The task is for failed authentication to be logged to Cisco ISE and also have a minimal impact on the users. Which command must the engineer configure?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
If a switchport is in "monitor mode" with the "authentication open" command, then even if ISE sends back a deny or "Access-Reject", the switch will ignore that and still allow traffic to pass. The whole point of "monitor mode" is to see what ISE would allow and not allow. So you can continue to fine-tune your ISE policies. So in ISE, you would see a red deny in the Radius Live Logs, but the switch would not block any traffic for that device. The user or device would not be impacted at all! Then once you are comfortable that ISE is doing what it is supposed to, then you can remove the "authentication open" command from the switchports. Only then will the switch enforce what ISE says.

For me here it's the answer C.
authentication open
